titleText: ‘I Did Not Collude,’ Kushner Says After Meeting With Senate Investigators
mainText: By MATT APUZZO and MAGGIE HABERMAN: Jared Kushner said he was unaware of the agenda of a June 2016 meeting at which Donald Trump Jr. expected to learn damaging information about Hillary Clinton.

titleText: Trump Asks Why ‘Beleaguered’ Sessions Isn’t Investigating Clinton
mainText: By EILEEN SULLIVAN: In a tweet on Monday, President Trump returned to campaign rhetoric, suggesting that Hillary Clinton should be the subject of an investigation into Russian ties, not him.

titleText: Anthony Scaramucci, New Communications Chief, Woos Trump on TV
mainText: By MAGGIE HABERMAN: Mr. Scaramucci, the hedge fund investor turned message strategist, took his tailored suits and butter-smooth style on his first official TV outing on Sunday.

titleText: For Trump and Putin, Sanctions Are a Setback Both Sought to Avoid
mainText: By DAVID E. SANGER: The expansion of American sanctions against Russia can be viewed as a result of two world leaders’ overplaying their hands.

titleText: White House Signals Acceptance of Russia Sanctions Bill
mainText: By PETER BAKER and ANDREW HIGGINS: President Trump expressed anger at Republicans who abandoned him on the legislation and forced his hand.

titleText: The Company Behind Many Surprise Emergency Room Bills
mainText: By JULIE CRESWELL, REED ABELSON and MARGOT SANGER-KATZ: A study by Yale researchers found that the rate of out-of-network doctor’s bills for customers of a big insurer jumped when EmCare entered a hospital.

titleText: Small Businesses Split Over Republican Health Plans
mainText: By STACY COWLEY: Small-business owners, some of the most vocal opponents of the Affordable Care Act, are divided over Republican plans to reverse much of the law.

titleText: The Mayor and the Restaurateur: How de Blasio Sought Help for an Early Donor
mainText: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM: Federal investigators, while declining to prosecute, still questioned City Hall’s conduct. Was the administration doing favors for contributors?

titleText: Hat. Rabbit. Spy Cam? Claims of Skulduggery at a Hot Magic Show
mainText: By JENNIFER SCHUESSLER: The magician Derek DelGaudio has tried to keep his work invisible on the internet. Did another professional secretly film his show?

titleText: My Gay Agenda
mainText: By JENNIFER FINNEY BOYLAN: Do I want “special rights”? You bet I do!

titleText: Why I Bring My Gun to School
mainText: By ANTONIA OKAFOR: There is a place for pro-Second Amendment black women in modern feminism.

titleText: Chuck Schumer: A Better Deal for American Workers
mainText: By CHUCK SCHUMER: Our party has failed to articulate a strong, bold economic program for the middle class. No longer.

titleText: A Dangerous Idea: Eliminating the Chemical Safety Board
mainText: By STEVE EARLY: The tiny federal agency investigates industrial fires and explosions, and its findings can prevent future accidents.

titleText: How to Feed Your Summer Crowd Without Going Crazy
mainText: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER: This season can be the worst, with kids home from school and friends dropping in. But here are methods for dealing with the madness.

titleText: The Author of ‘I Love Dick’ — on One Crazy Coincidence
mainText: As told to EMILY SPIVACK: When Chris Kraus set out to write a biography on Kathy Acker, she had no idea the surprising artistic connection she would discover they shared.

titleText: Is This the Woman Who Will Save Uber?
mainText: By SHEILA MARIKAR: Bozoma Saint John, the marketing star who’s worked with Beyoncé, Apple and more, brings humanism, Instagram savvy and Chanel to the beleaguered brand.

titleText: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 7, Episode 2 Recap: Dark Reunions
mainText: By JEREMY EGNER: On Sunday, characters connected in new and surprising ways all over Westeros.

titleText: California Today: Turmoil at U.S.C.
mainText: By MIKE McPHATE: Monday: “Egregious behavior” by a former dean, a ride along with immigration enforcers, and what $1,350 rents you in Los Angeles.

titleText: Parents of Charlie Gard, Ill British Infant, Abandon Effort to Prolong His Life
mainText: By DAN BILEFSKY: His parents accepted medical experts’ consensus that there was no realistic hope that an experimental therapy might save their son.

titleText: Leader Who Rebuilt Time Warner Empire Prepares an Exit
mainText: By EMILY STEEL: Jeffrey Bewkes, a quiet defender of CNN who has delivered Time Warner high returns, plans to leave the company if a merger with AT&T is approved.

titleText: Greece Looks to Turn a Corner After Years of Economic Pain
mainText: By LIZ ALDERMAN: The announcement that Athens would issue new bonds offered hope that one of Europe’s weakest economies might at last be weaning itself off international bailouts.

titleText: With More Ships in the Arctic, Fears of Disaster Rise
mainText: By HENRY FOUNTAIN: A decline in sea ice is allowing more marine travel, but experts say the remote region is unprepared to face an emergency at sea.

titleText: Aqsa Mosque Dispute Strains Israeli-Jordanian Alliance
mainText: By ISABEL KERSHNER: Jordan barred an Israeli Embassy security officer from leaving the country as Palestinians continued to protest Israeli security measures at the mosque.

titleText: ‘You Create That Chemistry’: How Actors Fall in Instant Love
mainText: By ALEXIS SOLOSKI: The foursome of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” talk trust, lust and the art of stage kissing.

titleText: Michael Phelps ‘Raced’ a ‘Shark,’ Kind Of. Not Really.
mainText: By VICTOR MATHER: A televised match race between the 23-time Olympic gold medalist and a great white shark seemed about as realistic as a sharknado.

titleText: Truck Driver Is Charged in Deaths of 10 Migrants in Texas
mainText: By DAVID MONTGOMERY, RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and MANNY FERNANDEZ: A federal prosecutor charged James M. Bradley Jr. with smuggling resulting in deaths. He could face life in prison or the death penalty.

titleText: U.S. Inflation Remains Low, and That’s a Problem
mainText: By BINYAMIN APPELBAUM: The Federal Reserve is struggling to hit its annual inflation target for the sixth straight year, suggesting that, once again, it may be too optimistic about the health of the economy.

titleText: Companies Rush to Develop ‘Utterly Transformative’ Gene Therapies
mainText: By DENISE GRADY: Gene therapy for cancer is becoming a reality but works best for blood cancers like leukemia and not yet in more common ones like lung cancer.

titleText: Bronx Hotline Helps People Make the Right Call After an Arrest
mainText: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL: With numbers often stored on phones and not remembered, a service helps put those arrested in touch with lawyers and relatives.
